thread.title_full: Ashes 2015: Live Scores, video, updates & highlights | First Test, Day 4 | The Advertiser

author: TYSON OTTO
title: Ashes 2015: Live Scores, video, updates & highlights | First Test, Day 4 | The
text:
AUSTRALIA has been embarrassed after a weak performance from the top order gifted England victory in the first Ashes Test in Cardiff.
Australia fell 169 runs short of England’s second innings lead of 411 runs, but the scoreboard flatters the tourists.
Australia’s record chase appeared to have a solid foundation heading into lunch on day four with David Warner and Steve Smith helping Australia to 1/97 in the final over of the first session.
Then it all went horribly, horribly wrong.
Warner fell to Moeen Ali on the last ball before lunch and when play resumed Australia’s batsmen failed to put up a fight.
The Aussies lost 5/25, melting under the heat of the England attack.
Only Mitchell Johnson was able to stand up for himself as he led a brave resistance to steer Australia from 6/122 to 7/223 with a knock of 77 off 94 balls.
If you take Johnson’s score out of the Australian side, they lost nine wickets for just 68 runs.
See how the carnage happened below.
2.01am — JOHNSON’S EXPLOSIVE CAMEO
Mitchell Johnson showed some Australians are still prepared to put up a fight. Source: Getty Images
MITCHELL Johnson made England work for his wicket - and that can’t be said for most of his teammates.
The left-handed batsman produced another back-against the wall fighting innings where re refused to be broken as easily as the Aussie top order.
Johnson’s lower order resistance at least took some of the shine off England’s jubilant ride to a series lead.
From Brad Haddin’s wicket with the Aussies at 6-122, Johnson led Australia to 7/223 before partner Mitchell Starc fell to a stunning group catch which ended in the hands of Adam Lyth at first slip.
Johnson fell to the bowling of Joe Root when he danced down the pitch and sent an edge straight to first slip Adam Lyth.
Johnson’s innings of 77 helped Australia to 9/242.
12.27 — SHANE WATSON FAILS WITH ANOTHER LBW
Shane Watson’s oversized front pad was his undoing yet again.
WHAT is it about Shane Watson that his teammates are unable to tell him not to challenge his LBW dismissals?
The Australian all-rounder was trapped walking across his stumps and again given out LBW when the Duke crashed into his front pad below the knee roll off the bowling of Mark Wood.
Incredibly, despite being shamed for his first innings howler decision to incorrectly challenge his leg-before dismissal, Watson walked up the pitch to discuss the delivery with nonstriker Mitchell Johnson before challenging the verdict yet again.
The Decision Review System showed the ball would have collected leg stump and Watson’s embarrassing streak of perplexing DRS reviews continues.
His dismissal left Australia 7/151.
Johnson and Watson’s partnership pulled Australia briefly out of its nose dive after the Aussies lost 5/25 to collapse to 6/122 in the second session of play.
11.08pm — AUSTRALIA COLLAPSES
Steve Smith has been sent back to the sheds. Source: AFP
When David Warner fell just before lunch - nobody could have seen the collapse about to unfold in Cardiff.
The Aussies lost 4/9 to crumble from 1/97 to 5/106 in a weak performance that will have a lasting impact for the remainder of the series.
Bang. Steve Smith fell to Stuart Broad after he edged a good delivery to Ian Bell at second slip.
Bang. Michael Clarke fell victim to Broad again when he chopped a thick outside edge to Ben Stokes at backwards point.
Bang. Adam Voges edged to English keeper Jos Buttler off the bowling of Mark Wood.
It was Smith who should feel the most anger at his dismissal. There was very little he could do to Broad’s darting cutter.
The left-handed batsman attempted to push at it outside off stump but ended up snicking it to Ian Bell at second slip.
Smith’s wicket left Australia 3/101 and gave England two wickets in seven deliveries.
10pm — WARNER DISMISSED AT LUNCH
David Warner was dismissed at a crucial moment in the first Test. Source: Getty Images
DAVID Warner was beginning to make England more than a little nervous as he blasted his way past 50 - only to be removed on the final ball before lunch.
Warner fell for 52 off the bowling of Moeen Ali to leave Australia 2/97 after an entertaining first session in Cardiff on day four of the first Test.
England still leads by 315 runs.
Warner was trapped on the crease by a ball that skidded on and struck Warner on the pads.
Australia 2-97 at lunch after David Warner's lbw. Smith 29 (45) to be joined by the skipper after the break. #Ashes pic.twitter.com/cbBErKNlji
— cricket.com.au (@CricketAus) July 11, 2015 The left-handed batsman brought up his 50 from 72 balls after really struggling to find his feet early in the day.
Warner scored just one run from his first 23 balls and Aussie greats Ian Healy and Mark Taylor admitted they were nervous at seeing the slashing opener struggling to counter the pace of the English bowlers.
“It’s probably as hard as I’ve seen him work at the start of an innings,” Taylor told Channel 9.
“He’s really trying to concentrate.”
Healy said: “David Warner isn’t watching the ball. He hasn’t followed the ball onto the bat. That’s why he’s not seeing it as well as he’d like.”
Warner and Smith had earlier pushed their partnership past 50 from just 41 balls with Smith scoring 18 from his first 20 balls.
It included an incredible over against the bowling of Ali who conceded 17 runs in his second over and was taken out of the attack with figures of 0/22 from two overs.
LIVE 1/69 "A 50 partnership from this pair, it's come in the blink of an eye." - @mcjnicholas . #Ashes #WWOS pic.twitter.com/20o336tusU
— Wide World of Sports (@WWOS9) July 11, 2015 8.43pm — CHRIS ROGERS EDGES TO SLIP
Stuart Broad landed the first blow for England. Source: AP
OPENER Chris Rogers was given a life and then failed to capitalise.
Rogers pushed nervously at a ball from Stuart Broad which flew to Ian Bell at second slip.
The field umpires called Rogers back briefly to review the decision to give him out because there was some conjecture over if the ball had travelled to Bell on the full.
Replays showed Bell just got his hands down in time.
LISTEN: Chris Rogers the first Australian wicket to fall in the second innings. http://t.co/Fh1YnAOgaQ #Ashes #ENGvAUS
— ABC Grandstand (@abcgrandstand) July 11, 2015 It left Australia 1/19, still 392 behind their target of 412.
It came after Joe Root dropped Rogers in the third over of the day when he spilled a thick edge diving to his left at third slip off the bowling of James Anderson.
LIVE 0/5 "Around the wicket works, a bit of extra bounce." - @michaelvaughan as Root puts Rogers down. #Ashes #WWOS pic.twitter.com/VXhUBM9QOR
— Wide World of Sports (@WWOS9) July 11, 2015 "David Warner shakes his head." - @michaelvaughan as England review the not our caught behind. #Ashes #WWOS pic.twitter.com/M3uMSYAEsh
— Wide World of Sports (@WWOS9) July 11, 2015
AUSTRALIA has not chased down more than 400 runs in the fourth innings of an Ashes test since the Leeds Test of 1948.
That is the incredible feat they will have to repeat if they are to stop England from snatching a series lead when play gets underway today with the home side defending a lead of 411 runs.
England is 10 wickets away from the series opening win and are heavy favourites, but records are made to be broken and it could very well be a special day in the history of cricket’s greatest rivalry.
These are the immortal run chases Australia must re-create in Cardiff.
"A few up the top there are in recent times." - Tubby on the highest successful run chases in Test matches. #Ashes pic.twitter.com/EmHr9wF5hz
— Wide World of Sports (@WWOS9) July 11, 2015 David Warner and Chris Rogers have the task of beginning Australia’s climb towards England’s massive lead.
Former Test great Ian Healy may have summed up the mood the best.
Ian Healy sums up what we're all thinking as he identifies exactly how the Aussies​ will win this #Ashes Test. WATCH: http://t.co/xZfFotQCwm
— cricket.com.au (@CricketAus) July 11, 2015 By the way, did you catch this yesterday?
It’s not quite the definition of former Test captain Steve Waugh’s ‘mental disintegration’ but there were definitely some feathers ruffled when Nathan Lyon and David Warner played a few mindgames with England all-rounder Ben Stokes.
Lyon and Warner mess with Stokes
Follow our live coverage below from 8pm.

Originally published as Australia’s pathetic Ashes collapse
